results.title: Succession from sand dune to forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Explains that succession is the process by which a given area changes slowly and continuously until it finally becomes a stable community. Shows one of the earliest and most thoroughly studied examples of this process on the shore of Lake Michigan
results.description:

results.title: Community
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Defines the ecological community as a complex network of interrelationships among a group of plants and animals adapted to the same general physical conditions, food chains and food webs.

results.title: Biology program; unit 1. Ecology
results.brief_description: Series of programs intended for upper secondary level students. Introduces the study of ecology by illustrating the wide variety of interrelationships between plants, animals and their environment.

results.title: What is ecology?
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Introduces the study of ecology by illustrating the wide variety of interrelationships between plants, animals and their environment. Introduces the major biomes of the world.

results.title: The Temperate deciduous forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 1. Ecology”
Illustrates the complex network of plant and animal relationships that make up the temperate deciduous forest community. Shows the adaptations of animals and deciduous plants to seasonal changes.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 1. Ecology”
Illustrates the complex network of plant and animal relationships that make up the temperate deciduous forest community. Shows the adaptations of animals and deciduous plants to seasonal changes.

results.title: The Sea
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Illustrates basic concepts of marine ecology, and shows the interrelationship between living things in the sea, their dependence on each other and on the conditions of the marine environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Illustrates basic concepts of marine ecology, and shows the interrelationship between living things in the sea, their dependence on each other and on the conditions of the marine environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Population ecology
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Shows how environmental conditions such as natural enemies and food factors can help increase or reduce births and deaths. Discusses how humans have created the birth surplus over death called the population explosion. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Shows how environmental conditions such as natural enemies and food factors can help increase or reduce births and deaths. Discusses how humans have created the birth surplus over death called the population explosion. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Plankton and the open sea
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Pictures typical forms of plankton and demonstrates the importance of minute plankton organisms to marine food chains. Also shows how plankton is studied. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Ecology of a hot spring: life at high temperatures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Uses the hot springs of Yellowstone National Park as a laboratory for the study of organisms that can survive the effects of high temperatures. Suitable for upper secondary level.
